description: Answers to questions about the case of a Kentucky clerk who has refused to issue marriage licenses to any couples, gay or straight.
title: What’s Next for Kim Davis and Kentucky’s Gay Marriage Standoff
title_page: What’s Next for Kim Davis and Kentucky’s Gay Marriage Standoff - The New York Times
text:
Rowan County, Ky., issued marriage licenses on Friday for the first time in more than two months, including the first licenses ever to be issued to same-sex couples. That change came a day after a federal judge, David L. Bunning, sent the county clerk to jail for contempt of court after she defied his order to resume issuing marriage licenses.
The clerk, Kim Davis, stopped issuing licenses after the Supreme Court’s landmark ruling in June legalizing same-sex marriage. Ms. Davis said that violated her Apostolic Christian beliefs and that rather than discriminate, she would not grant any licenses.
Below are some of the questions most often raised about the case, and some answers:
